thread.title_full: Carol Lloyd funeral Brisbane music Railroad Gin | Cairns Post

title: Carol Lloyd funeral Brisbane music Railroad Gin | Cairns Post
text:
QUEENSLAND rock pioneer Carol Lloyd has been remembered as a “warrior of the art world” at a public funeral service held in Brisbane today. 
The 68-year-old passed away last week following a lengthy battle with terminal pulmonary fibrosis. 
This morning her family and friends, including musicians, politicians and media personalities, gathered at St John’s Cathedral in Brisbane to celebrate her life. Carol Lloyd tribute 
Lifelong friend Bob Blasdall, who worked on Lloyd’s first music video, delivered a touching eulogy revealing funny anecdotes and treasured memories from their past. 
“She was a restless warrior of the art world, warrior of the words and wonderful warrior of song,” he said. 
Performing with Railroad Gin and later with her own band, Lloyd achieved immense success in the charts and became the first Australian artist to be offered an international publishing contract. media_camera Premier and Arts Minister Annastacia Palaszczuk addresses Carol Lloyd’s funeral. Picture: Liam Kidston 
Brisbane-based country musician Troy Cassar-Daley attended the funeral and said Lloyd broke down barriers for female artists. 
“Everyone thought that rock and roll was just a male dominated area and I think Carol came in and just booted the door down and proved a girl could do it to,” he said. 
He said Lloyd was compassionate and “really cared about the artists”. 
“Her legacy will be the younger generation of female singers coming through; she has empowered them,” he said. media_camera Music was fittingly a big part of the celebration of Carol Lloyd’s life. Picture: Liam Kidston 
Premier and Arts Minister Annastacia Palaszczuk attended the funeral with her father, Labor stalwart Henry Palaszczuk, and spoke about her friendship with Lloyd. 
“Whenever she walked into the room, you immediately felt her great warmth and charm. Carol had one big, big heart,” she said. 
From playing to crowds of 29,000 at the Brisbane Botanic Gardens to outperforming Suzi Quatro at her own show, Lloyd’s legacy was one of breaking barriers for Australian female artists. media_camera Country artist Troy Cassar-Daley at the funeral of Brisbane rock trailblazer Carol Lloyd. Picture: Liam Kidston 
Ms Palaszczuk said she was proud to support the inaugural Carol Lloyd Award, to be given to an emerging female singer songwriter in Queensland. 
“It is fitting that her memory is celebrated through this award,” Ms Palaszczuk said. 
“Farewell Ruby Tuesday, goodbye my friend. 
“You were a great Queenslander, you loved your family and you loved your friends and your memory will always, always live on.” 
The services included musical performances from Queensland artists Alison St Ledger and William Barton, and ended to the strains of Lloyd’s cover of the Rolling Stones’ Ruby Tuesday . media_camera Carol Lloyd at the peak of her success media_camera
